newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Japan, EU challenge Indonesia car policy in WTO.
newsitem.headline: Japan, EU challenge Indonesia car policy in WTO.

text.p: Japan, strongly backed by the European Union, on Wednesday asked for creation of a World Trade Organisation (WTO) panel to look into Indonesia's controversial "national car" policy.

The request, presented to the WTO's Dispute Settlement Body (DSB), was blocked by Indonesia which said it was continuing consultations with Japan on the dispute and insisted the policy did not violate global trading rules.
But under DSB procedures, creation of a panel will be automatic at the next meeting on May 23 if Japan pursues the complaint.
A panel ruling could be expected by the end of the year, although this could be appealed by either side.

Trade sources said a Japanese official told the DSB on Wednesday that Tokyo understood Indonesia's desire to build its own automobile industry, but argued this could only be done in conformity with Jakarta's obligations under WTO accords.

An EU trade diplomat said Brussels, which has also had consultations with Indonesia over the issue, was seriously concerned that the policy violated WTO rules and voiced firm backing for the Japanese request.

The policy gives 100 per cent exemptions from tariffs and luxury taxes for three years to a company controlled by the youngest son of Indonesia's President Suharto and which produces a sedan known as the Timor.

Japan, the EU and the United States -- which has also begun a dispute process against Jakarta in the WTO on the issue -- see this as unfair discrimination against their car companies who have a large share of Indonesia's booming car market.
